title: Canon law of the Catholic Church
summary: The canon law of the Catholic Church ("canon law" comes from Latin ius canonicum[1]) is the system of laws and ecclesiastical legal principles made and enforced by the hierarchical authorities of the Catholic Church to regulate its external organization and government and to order and direct the activities of Catholics toward the mission of the Church.[2] It was the first modern Western legal system[3] and is the oldest continuously functioning legal system in the West,[4][5] while the unique traditions of Eastern Catholic canon law govern the 23 Eastern Catholic particular churches sui iuris.
